prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The question is whether the author is in the wrong for not buying their family members Christmas gifts. Let's break down the situation.

First, the author received a $400 gift card, which they won. They bragged about it on Instagram, and their sister saw it. The author's mom then got involved and made them feel pressured to buy gifts for the sister, cousins, etc. The author felt this was obnoxious and decided not to spend the money on family, instead spending it on themselves. The mom was upset and there was an argument.

So, the main points here are: the author is 15, which is a teenager, still young. They were given a gift card they won, which is their money. They were pressured by their mom to buy gifts for family members, including cousins they don't see often. The author felt this was unreasonable and decided not to comply. The mom reacted negatively, leading to conflict.

Now, considering if the author is in the wrong. The author was not obligated to spend their own money on family. The mom and family members didn't contribute to the gift card, so the author has the right to use it as they see fit. The pressure from the mom to buy gifts for others, especially for people the author doesn't see often, could be seen as pushing their own expectations onto the child's funds. The author might have a valid point about autonomy over their money. However, in some family dynamics, there might be an unspoken expectation to share or buy gifts during the holidays. But the mom's approach seems to have been overbearing, especially after the initial refusal. The author's decision to prioritize their own spending after feeling pressured could be justified. The age of the author (15) is also a factor; they might be developing their independence.

On the other hand, maybe the author could have handled it more tactfully. They could have explained their decision earlier, perhaps before using the money, to avoid the last-minute conflict. But the situation involved the mom taking the gift card and then adding more people to the list, which might have pushed the author's buttons. The mom's reaction, including guilt-tripping and yelling, isn't helpful. 

So, considering all this, the author isn't necessarily in the wrong because they have the right to their own money and the stress from the family's demands. The mom's actions were probably more at fault here. Therefore, the answer is B (the author is not in the wrong).
